verses.text: Now Jehoshaphat had great riches and honor, and he allied himself with Ahab through marriage.
verses.comment: Translates the Hebrew phrase for alliance by marriage literally.

verses.text: After some years, he went down to Ahab in Samaria. Ahab slaughtered many sheep and cattle for him and the people with him, and persuaded him to attack Ramoth-gilead.
verses.comment: Maintains the Hebrew idiom 'went down' meaning to go on a journey.

verses.text: Ahab king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat king of Judah, 'Will you go with me to Ramoth-gilead?' He answered him, 'I am as you are, and my people are as your people. We will be with you in the battle.'
verses.comment: Hebrew idiom 'I am as you are' preserved for accuracy.

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat said to the king of Israel, 'Please seek the word of the LORD first.'
verses.comment: 'Word of the LORD' is a direct translation of the Hebrew phrase.

verses.text: So the king of Israel gathered the prophets, four hundred men, and said to them, 'Should we go to war against Ramoth-gilead, or should I refrain?' They said, 'Go up, for God will give it into the king’s hand.'
verses.comment: Retains 400 prophets from the Hebrew text.

verses.text: But Jehoshaphat said, 'Is there not here another prophet of the LORD, that we may ask him as well?'

The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, 'There is still one man by whom we can inquire of the LORD, Micaiah son of Imlah. But I hate him, for he never prophesies good about me, only evil.' Jehoshaphat said, 'Let not the king say so.'
verses.comment: "Let not the king say so" translates a soft Hebrew rebuke.

verses.text: Then the king of Israel called an officer and said, 'Bring quickly Micaiah son of Imlah.'

Now the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah were sitting each on his throne, clothed in their robes. They were sitting at the threshing floor at the entrance of the gate of Samaria, and all the prophets were prophesying before them.
Zedekiah son of Chenaanah had made horns of iron for himself and said, 'This is what the LORD says: With these you will gore the Arameans until they are destroyed.'
verses.comment: 'Arameans' translates 'Syrians' from the Hebrew.

verses.text: And all the prophets prophesied so, saying, 'Go up to Ramoth-gilead and prosper, for the LORD will give it into the king’s hand.'
The messenger who went to call Micaiah said to him, 'See, the words of the prophets are all favorable to the king. Let your word be like one of theirs, and speak good.'
But Micaiah said, 'As the LORD lives, I will say what my God says.'
verses.comment: Translation keeps the Hebrew formula 'As the LORD lives.'

verses.text: When he came to the king, the king said to him, 'Micaiah, shall we go to Ramoth-gilead to battle, or shall I refrain?' He answered, 'Go up and succeed, for they will be given into your hand.'
verses.comment: Keeps Micaiah's initial ironic positive answer.

verses.text: But the king said to him, 'How many times shall I make you swear that you will tell me nothing but the truth in the name of the LORD?'
Then he said, 'I saw all Israel scattered on the mountains, like sheep without a shepherd. And the LORD said, "These have no master; let each return to his house in peace."'
verses.comment: Retains shepherd imagery.

verses.text: Then the king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, 'Did I not tell you that he would not prophesy good about me, but only evil?'
And Micaiah said, 'Therefore hear the word of the LORD: I saw the LORD sitting on his throne, and all the host of heaven standing on his right and on his left.'
verses.comment: 'Host of heaven' is a literal translation of the Hebrew.

verses.text: The LORD said, 'Who will entice Ahab king of Israel, that he may go up and fall at Ramoth-gilead?' And one said this, and another said that.
verses.comment: Retains the courtroom setting and counsel scene.

verses.text: Then a spirit came forward and stood before the LORD and said, 'I will entice him.' The LORD said to him, 'How?'
And he said, 'I will go out and be a lying spirit in the mouth of all his prophets.' And the LORD said, 'You will entice him, and you will succeed. Go out and do so.'
verses.comment: 'Lying spirit' is a direct translation from Hebrew.

verses.text: Now therefore, the LORD has put a lying spirit in the mouth of these your prophets. The LORD has spoken evil concerning you.'
verses.comment: 'Spoken evil' means pronounced disaster (standard Hebrew idiom).

verses.text: Then Zedekiah son of Chenaanah came near and struck Micaiah on the cheek and said, 'Which way did the Spirit of the LORD go from me to speak to you?'
Micaiah said, 'Behold, you will see on that day when you go into an inner room to hide yourself.'
verses.comment: 'Inner room' translates the Hebrew for a private chamber.

verses.text: Then the king of Israel said, 'Take Micaiah and return him to Amon the governor of the city and to Joash the king’s son,'
and say, 'Thus says the king, "Put this man in prison and feed him with only a little bread and water until I return safely."'
verses.comment: Literal translation of the phrase 'feed him meager bread and water.'

verses.text: Micaiah said, 'If you return safely, the LORD has not spoken by me.' And he said, 'Listen, all you peoples!'
verses.comment: Ends prophetic oracle with a call to all the people.

verses.text: So the king of Israel and Jehoshaphat king of Judah went up to Ramoth-gilead.
The king of Israel said to Jehoshaphat, 'I will disguise myself and go into the battle, but you wear your robes.' And the king of Israel disguised himself, and they went into the battle.
Now the king of Aram had commanded the captains of his chariots, saying, 'Do not fight with anyone small or great, but only with the king of Israel.'
verses.comment: 'Aram' translates Hebrew for 'Syria.'

verses.text: When the captains of the chariots saw Jehoshaphat, they said, 'It is the king of Israel!' So they turned to attack him, but Jehoshaphat cried out, and the LORD helped him; God drew them away from him.
When the captains of the chariots saw that he was not the king of Israel, they turned away from pursuing him.

But a certain man drew his bow at random and struck the king of Israel between the scale armor and the breastplate. So he said to his charioteer, 'Turn around and carry me out of the battle, for I am wounded.'
verses.comment: 'Drew his bow at random' is a literal translation; 'scale armor and breastplate' per Hebrew phrasing.

verses.text: The battle grew fierce that day, and the king of Israel was propped up in his chariot facing the Arameans until evening. At sunset he died.
verses.comment: Last phrase is literal: 'at the time of the going down of the sun he died.'
